product_name: SanDisk 256GB Extreme microSDXC UHS-I Memory Card with Adapter - Up to 190MB/s, C10, U3, V30, 4K, 5K, A2, Micro SD Card - SDSQXAV-256G-GN6MA
title: Which size and how many do you really only need?
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on April 16, 2023
text: I recently purchased the SanDisk 128GB Extreme microSDXC UHS-I Memory Card with Adapter and have been thoroughly impressed with its performance. This memory card boasts impressive speeds of up to 190MB/s read speeds, which is powered by SanDisk QuickFlow Technology. I was skeptical at first, but after testing it out with my compatible devices, I can confirm that the speed is lightning-fast and saves me a lot of time during file transfers.One thing I appreciate about this memory card is that it pairs perfectly with the SanDisk Professional PRO-READER SD and microSD to achieve maximum speeds (sold separately). If you're someone who values fast transfer speeds, I would definitely recommend investing in this reader to make the most out of your SanDisk memory card.Another aspect of this memory card that I find impressive is the fast write speeds of up to 90MB/s. This is particularly helpful for fast shooting and quick data transfers. I have used this memory card in my DSLR and it has not disappointed me in terms of speed or storage capacity.The SanDisk 128GB Extreme microSDXC UHS-I Memory Card is also 4K and 5K UHD-ready with UHS Speed Class 3 (U3) and Video Speed Class 30 (V30). This means that it is perfect for recording high-quality videos and taking high-resolution photos. I have used this memory card to capture 4K videos on my compatible device and the results have been fantastic.In addition to its impressive speed and performance, the SanDisk 128GB Extreme microSDXC UHS-I Memory Card is also rated A2 for faster loading and in-app performance. This is particularly helpful for those who frequently use apps or games that require a lot of memory and speed.Overall, I would highly recommend the SanDisk 128GB Extreme microSDXC UHS-I Memory Card with Adapter for anyone who needs a reliable and fast memory card. Its speed and performance are top-notch, and the extra features like A2 performance and compatibility with SanDisk Professional PRO-READER SD and microSD make it a worthwhile investment.

product_name: SanDisk 256GB Extreme microSDXC UHS-I Memory Card with Adapter - Up to 190MB/s, C10, U3, V30, 4K, 5K, A2, Micro SD Card - SDSQXAV-256G-GN6MA
title: It’s Sooo Convenient to Have an Extra 128GB SD Card in Your Phone!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on March 2, 2023
text: I tend to fill up all the available memory space on my devices, so I really appreciate the ability to add memory to my phone (or anything else, actually), but especially my phone.  I use an app that stores all of my encrypted messages as backups on my phone (up to 12GB now), and it backs them up on a daily basis, keeping the older copies of the backup.  That adds up to serious memory use after a short time!  The only thing to do it to have to delete the old ones every few days or give up current backups…or get a new 128 GB SD card to put in the phone.  So, when I saw this SanDisk 128GB Extreme microSDXC, I ordered it.Whenever I get a new SD card the first thing I do is to fill it up with large files.  That tells me two important things:  1.  The write speed of the drive or card (in this case averaging about 30 MB/sec – you need their card reader for the much faster advertised speeds), and 2.  Whether or not it’s really the size it claims to be.  I’ve bought four different SD cards/Thumb drives that claimed to be huge (1 TB) but were actually 32 GB drives that had the hardware on the card jimmied so as to appear to be larger.  The drives would appear to copy the files correctly, but anything over the actual capacity was not really copied, only its name.  I didn’t expect that there would be any difficulty with this card (it being SanDisk and sold by Amazon), and there wasn’t.  I’m glad to say that this 128 GB SD Card actually stores the correct number of bytes (about 117 GB which is really what the 128 GB means – advertising!  Yikes!).  I just popped it into my phone and formatted it as an internal drive (I could have not formatted it and just used it as storage, but I prefer that it be integrated more closely with the phone).So, I’m very glad that I got this SanDisk 128GB card.  It’s everything that it claims to be!

product_name: SanDisk 256GB Extreme microSDXC UHS-I Memory Card with Adapter - Up to 190MB/s, C10, U3, V30, 4K, 5K, A2, Micro SD Card - SDSQXAV-256G-GN6MA
title: Required reformatting before use on Mac OS
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on March 30, 2023
text: I bought this disk for Mac OS TimeMachine backup.  When I went to reformat using the Mac diskutil applications the option for APFS was not presented.  The APFS format is required for efficient backups.  However, I was able to reformat to APFS on the commandline.Use "diskutil list" to show what the disk names are. Mine was disk4% diskutil partitionDisk disk4 GPT APFS  FooBar  100%  (Note: GPT is requried on this command.)Once this was completed the disk had a proper GUID "Scheme" so an APFS was creatable. And normal "diskutil" operations are available.

title: Slower than I expected
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 17, 2023
text: I have at least 5 micro sd card from SanDisk and none of them ever had a write below 70 MByte/s using H2testw but this 256 GB advertised to have higher specs is actually slower on Writing speed of 50 MByte/s. I would've given it a higher rating if not for this low writing speed. The reading was within the range. If you buy this micro sd card and the writing and reading aren't above 75 MByte/s, then try a different adapter, ports and computer and if you still have lower than 75 MByte/s, then your card might be fake or is a defect.

title: Not getting speeds manufacturer claims. Not a hardware issue.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on February 7, 2023
text: I bought the 512gb version. While this card is reasonably fast I'm not getting the speeds the manufacturer claims on the packaging. I'm also not getting speeds some other reviewers are getting. I'm not sure what is going on. People that have posted screen shots of benchmarks have not posted them of 512 gb version so that might be a possible reason. I have tried multiple USB ports on my PC including 3.2 Gen 2 10Gbps (MSI X570 Tomahawk motherboard). I'm also using a high end 3.2 Gen 2 10Gbps card reader (ProGrade PG08). It is not my hardware. I get expected speeds on other faster SD cards I have. I bought the card from Amazon and not third party.

product_name: SanDisk 256GB Extreme microSDXC UHS-I Memory Card with Adapter - Up to 190MB/s, C10, U3, V30, 4K, 5K, A2, Micro SD Card - SDSQXAV-256G-GN6MA
title: Always check item & buy from Amazon only!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 2, 2022
text: I’ve been so terrified of buying these 1TB Sandisk due to horror stories of fake vs real. The crazy posts of threads about bad cards frying up inside Nintendo Switch and laptops. I have been buying the official Nintendo cards due to these fears but always on sale never full price! Got a Steam Deck couple months ago and needed a 1TB so I chanced it!Compared the one for Nintendo from Sandisk to the ones I received and they all matched. Green backing where you can almost make out the card circuits and a black label for identification and where it’s made. The cardboard wasn’t a pain to open but the plastic where it houses the sd card and provided reader was a pain!After observing the cards from thread posts of those reporting overheating causing melted cards inside Nintendo Switch and laptops, I realized those cards all had full black backing no visual of the circuits at all. Turns out the one from both threads both OP later reported the cards fakes. So be careful, check them physically, run speed tests or for security call Sandisk customer service for help.Always buy from Amazon directly for better coverage! I got lucky and all of mine 6 cards to be exact, all on different Switches and 2 Steam Decks work! Zero issues and been using them regularly. Very happy with the storage especially now with holiday sales and being able to have all digital stuff ready on devices.Don’t buy these at full retail price, wait for sales like Prime Days or Black Friday/Cyber Monday! You can get 2 for the price of one during those days! Keep them on a wishlist so you see updates on discounts!

product_name: SanDisk 256GB Extreme microSDXC UHS-I Memory Card with Adapter - Up to 190MB/s, C10, U3, V30, 4K, 5K, A2, Micro SD Card - SDSQXAV-256G-GN6MA
title: Don't doubt it till you test it out! Looks can be deceiving!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on October 15, 2022
text: Tl:dr  it really depends on your card reader or devices if it can handle the card actual speed.You should atleast know by now you're not going to get the full advertised amount of storage when it comes to any type of memory storage. That being say, my card was off by almost 60GB give it take. I'm happy with that.When i first received the card, my first reaction was that I got a fake card. Normally, the extreme card have a golden color right. This one looks like the golden color was an off color with a slight greenish color. It looks like a bootleg card that scream fake at first glance.First reaction was to pop into a card reader and do some testing on the computer. The advertised read and write for the 1TB card was 190MB/130MB but i was averaging at around 80s MB read /70s MB write. I was willing to live with that because for a microsd card, that write speed is good enough for me as the read speed didn't really matter for me because if i truly only care about the read speed, I would have bought the Ultra A1 version and save a little $$ instead but I wanted a decent write speed and it checks out.But, curiosity got the best of me. So i read through the reviews on here and some say they got fake cards, others are getting speeds close to advertised, while some are getting around the same speed i got.I didn't want to order an actual card reader just to test the darn thing and let it collect dust afterwards. So i order Lexar microsd card usb 3.2 reader on Amazon to do the testing since i know I'll probably use that more than a actual card reader and it's cheaper.Low and behold, speed checks out. Not exactly as advertised but was averaging around 160s read / 120s write. So don't knock it as a fake until you test it out yourself because i know i almost did. Looks can be deceiving.

title: Macbook Pro 14 SD Slot - Actual Speeds
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on January 5, 2023
text: For those of you that want to use this in a M1 MacBook Pro 14 SD slot, here are the speed numbers that you can probably expect with a generic adapter:SanDisk 1TB Extreme (SDSQXAV-1T00-GN6MA): Write: 53.1 MB/s & Read: 83.2 MB/sThese values vary slightly depending on size of files used on the tests.  (See my photo)Note that this card advertises that you can get Read speeds of 190 MB/s.  However, keep in mind that those speeds are under ideal conditions and using SanDisk’s own reader that uses a proprietary protocol to achieve that.Realistically, most of us will be using the UHS-I speed of our hardware.  In my case on the MBP14, that is 104MB/s for the slot.  Without the proprietary Sandisk hardware the speeds are lower and you will most likely see speeds closer to what I have above — so temper your expectations and buy accordingly.

product_name: SanDisk 256GB Extreme microSDXC UHS-I Memory Card with Adapter - Up to 190MB/s, C10, U3, V30, 4K, 5K, A2, Micro SD Card - SDSQXAV-256G-GN6MA

text: If you use a GoPro or other action camera regularly, you know that having a quality cards matters. You need enough performance to do high res video at fairly high frame rates without hiccups. You also need it to be reliable so you don't get errors or corrupted files. These are the cards to use, whichever size you pick. SanDisk is the leader in this market for a reason, and the Extreme series continue to perform wonderfully.Sure, you can save a few bucks with some off brand, but if it was worth recording it was worth not risking it to a low quality memory card.There are decent alternatives, but they don't make it as easy to know which cards are suitable for what use. Demanding application? SanDisk Extreme, problem solved. With everyone else I have to carefully check the specs of each option, and my time has value to me.

title: A Large Capacity Storage Card
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 30, 2022
text: This card is for my security camera video storage. A large capacity card is desirable.  It doesn't have to be very fast, but it must be reliable.  This card is both.  I went with SanDisk because I feel that it will deliver the capacity it advertises (in this case it is 256GB).  In the past I have found that unknown brand named memory cards and thumb drives may not have the advertised capacities even though they have been rigged to display it from your computer.  There are very few uses where that would not be a big problem.

title: The SanDisk 512GB Extreme Is Fast, Consistent, and Reasonably Priced.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 13, 2022
text: As the headline says... "The SanDisk 512GB Extreme Is Fast, Consistent, and Reasonably Priced." There are many companies that produce and sell Micro SD-Cards these days, but I have always purchased the SanDisk Micro SD-Cards for various/good reasons... (1) Unlike other companies whose main production focus is not that of producing memory cards, SanDisk's primary focus has always been the business of memory cards... SanDisk, along with Panasonic and Toshiba introduced the Micro SD-Card in August 1999... so there's that going for SanDisk - it's their creation...!!! (2) Their fast performance, stability, reliability, endurance-over-time, and reasonable prices are top-notch, so I keep going back to SanDisk... Why wouldn't I...?

product_name: SanDisk 256GB Extreme microSDXC UHS-I Memory Card with Adapter - Up to 190MB/s, C10, U3, V30, 4K, 5K, A2, Micro SD Card - SDSQXAV-256G-GN6MA
title: Excellent 1TB micro SD Card
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 11, 2022
text: I bought the 1TB gold and red card. gives 80+ MB/s write speeds on my Lenovo T14 on the built in card reader. The only con is, for the 1TB card, there is a stack of memory chips on the bottom surface (not the label surface but the other surface) - so the bottom surface is not flat. The chip instead of being flush, projects a teeny tiny bit above the thickness of the memory card. This is unlike the 64GB and 128GB cards I've bought in the past. So be warned. I think it should still fit into most microSD card slots, but something to think about. Love that I added 1TB of additional storage to my laptop by just sticking a microSD card into it!

title: First!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on July 1, 2022
text: OmGzz FiRsT yUo GuYs!!!!!!1Wow. This IS exciting. Give me a moment...I'm verklempt.[breathes into paper bag, bends over...hands rested upon knees]Whew..ok, ok. So, it all started when Amazon suggested I take a look at a "newer version" of the tried n true 128GB SanSisk Extreme microSDXC I was about to happily purchase for the upteenth time. This one destined for a new action camera. That fateful click brought me here....to seemingly the exact same product page but sans reviews. Not even *one*?No, fam. Nada.My mystery-man, investigative skills were put to the test. But I would eventually unravel the truth like friggin Angela Lansbury, y'all:I'm being tracked by the Illuminati, fell right into the honey pot and a tracker bug is implanted in my card. That or this is just a new model lineup of the best value in micro flash-memory on the market.I'll let you decide.I will say this, however: the card is legit. Genuine SanDisk providing genuine Solid-State speed. I won't bore you with graphs and figures of my findings. Pffft...who needs em? What I will say is, I love you and would never lie to you. You'll be happy if you buy this card and I WANT that for you!So who'll join me in adding theirs, the second, third...the eighteen-thousandth review for this digital storage legend in the making? Who's coming with me?#SanDisk4Lyfe

title: This Card is Legit
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 17, 2022
text: The first thing I did when I received this card was to verify that it was authentic.  I fired up an Ubuntu VM and did an f3write and f3read.  I only took a screen shot of the results of the f3read...  It passed and had an average write speed of 78.4 MB/s using a USB3 port.I then burned a Linux distro image to it for my Rasberry Pi4 and this card works perfectly... This card is replacing a cheaper 256GB that I purchased from Amazon (and returning)--that card would not work in my Pi.

title: Genuine SanDisk microSD Card
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on July 22, 2022
text: Verified Serial Number with SanDisk support.Official SD Card Formatter sets 512kb cluster size. Full Format reported no errors.H2testw reports "Only 976309 of 976312 MByte tested," as expected. ~30mbps write speed on USB2.0. ~110 write speed, ~130 read speed on USB3.0. Negative reviews based on slow speed are more than likely based on the microSD card's speed being bottlenecked by computer port, USB (e.g. A to C) adapter speed, or by card reader rather than there being any fault with the card itself.Card was impressively hot while during the test. But it cooled down soon after H2testw concluded its results, and card appeared undamaged. Read and write speeds afterward were unchanged.Tools used:USB2.0: Samsung OEM OTG USB-A to USB-C adapterUSB3.0: 4-in-1 Anker USB HubmicroSD Card Reader: Kingston MobileLite Plus USB 3.2 microSDHC/SDXC UHS-II Card Reader (MLPM)Port: Thunderbolt / USB 4 port

title: Overheats while recording 4K 30FPS video on Action Cam
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on September 1, 2022
text: I noticed about 10 to 15 minutes of recording 4k 30FPS video that my camera would suddenly say that my card is slow. I once pulled out the card and i noticed it was hot. I thought maybe is a was a fault on the camera but to make sure I did a test using a flash card testing software called "H2testw" and the card overheated under the "Read Test" verifying the files that were written that check for corrupt or damaged cards. After around 10 minutes I would hear my laptop make a sound as if a USB device was disconnected and reconnected and I would receive this error on my testing software. and i immediately check the card and found it to be very hot to the touch.So it seams this card may be good for photos or low demand recording such as 720o or 1080p. But 10-15 minutes of 4k video is just too much demand and the card overheats and seems to disconnect as a possible safety feature or just plain failure to continue from the heat the card itself generates.

product_name: SanDisk 256GB Extreme microSDXC UHS-I Memory Card with Adapter - Up to 190MB/s, C10, U3, V30, 4K, 5K, A2, Micro SD Card - SDSQXAV-256G-GN6MA
title: Either faulty out of the package, or too "advanced" for both a Windows 10 pc and a brand new tablet.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on January 28, 2023
text: Absolute garbage. I've purchased Sandisk memory cards before from Amazon and they have been hit or miss, but this is the first time I've had one that was completely unusable right out of the package. Bought the 256GB Extreme microSDXC UHS-I Memory Card to use in a new Samsung A8 tablet, but the tablet couldn't read the card and kept saying it needed to be formatted. The formatting process would then stall at 20% and would never complete. Figured I might have screwed up and somehow purchased a card that wasn't compatible with my tablet, so I removed the card, inserted it into the included SD card adapter (making sure the switch was set to the unlocked setting), and inserted that into my Windows 10 Dell Inspiron 16 Plus. Again a message appeared saying the card needed to be formatted. However, no matter which formatting options were selected, a pop-up message repeatedly appeared stating that Windows was unable to complete the format. Furthermore, my PC showed the card's capacity as only 30.6 MB (MB?? not even GB??), so basically the entire advertised storage capacity is just... not there.In the end I wasn't able to get anywhere using any of the solutions that Sandisk's product support and my google search efforts brought up. Even Command Prompt wasn't able to format the drive or detect any partitions other than the 30.6 MB one. After wasting almost two hours I gave up. While it's possible that there's some magical driver or software I'm missing which could fix everything, it isn't worth the massive headache of trying to figure all of it out when all I wanted was simple plug and play storage. It's also possible it was a fake, however the packaging was identical to other Sandisk cards I've purchased in the past and it appeared to be unopened. Absolute waste of $30; go buy an SD card from anywhere else.

product_name: SanDisk 256GB Extreme microSDXC UHS-I Memory Card with Adapter - Up to 190MB/s, C10, U3, V30, 4K, 5K, A2, Micro SD Card - SDSQXAV-256G-GN6MA

title: Sandisk does not stand behind their product...
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on March 4, 2023
text: Purchased two SanDisk 1TB Extreme microSDXC UHS-I Memory Card over the past two months - both of which failed with in a week of use.  The first failed card was sent back to Amazon and I received a quick refund.  The second was sent to Sandisk with an understanding that they would send me off a replacement.  It has now been over a month since Sandisk has confirmed receipt of the failed memory card - yet, they still have not sent me out a replacement.  Every time I reach out to them they tell me that the replacement card will be sent out over the next 24 to 48 hours.  Yet when I go on their website to check to see if the replacement drive has been shipped - I see that, in fact, nothing has been sent.  Given my recent experience I will now be buying memory cards for companies other than Sandisk.

title: ESD (Electrostatic discharge) risk upon opening package!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 18, 2020
text: You'd think an electronic component manufacturer would know that peeling a plastic sheet away from another piece of plastic to open a package on an ESD sensitive component (the SD card) would know better!  As I peeled open the package, it had a static cling to my fingers!  Wow.  Hope you have a ground strap or ionizer to dissipate the charge before you touch the sd card or else you risk damaging the device when it discharges into it when you pull it out of the packaging.  Google "ESD" and "Roger Peirce"  (great guy - knows ESD)

title: Card failed after first use, has been in RMA for 18 days and appears lost.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 30, 2022
text: Moved 80GB worth of files from a desktop PC to a laptop, safely ejecting the card from each. When I put the card back into the PC it could still see and access the files but couldn't remove them. Card could not be formatted, or altered in any way. Basic troubleshooting led to a conclusion of "card failure". Created an RMA ticket and mailed in back to Sandisk under warranty on 12/12/22. I got an email on 12/29/22 saying if they don't receive it, Sandisk will close the case. Stay away. It's not worth the trouble. I've got $150.00 out of pocket and the only thing I have to show for it is a shipping receipt from USPS.

title: Received a Bad SDCard, Buyer Beware.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 4, 2021
text: I bought this card for my Roku Premier to expand the memory. I put the card in, and the Roku went through the formatting, but was showing 100% used. Restarted the Roku, and it did not show that a memory card was installed.I checked the Roku support site, and the card is compatible with my Roku. I tried formatting the card in my laptop (as suggested by Roku support), but I was unable to format it (I've formatted other SD cards before without issues. I tried to format the card in my cell phone, but I was unable to do so.  The card is definitely defected, and not worth the effort to go through the return process and drop the package off at a UPS store. I bought another brand of SD card for my Roku, and it worked perfectly.

title: So Affordable !!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 11, 2023
text: The SanDisk 128GB Extreme microSDXC UHS-I memory card is a top-of-the-line option for those in need of high-speed, high-capacity storage for their devices. With read speeds of up to 190MB/s and write speeds of up to 160MB/s, it's perfect for recording 4K and 5K video, perfect for GoPro an so affordable compared to that sold on gopro website, as well as capturing high-resolution photos. The card is also rated U3, V30, and A2, meaning it's suitable for high-performance applications and has a minimum of A2 class performance level. Additionally, the included adapter makes it easy to transfer files from the card to a computer or other device. Overall, I highly recommend the SanDisk 128GB Extreme microSDXC UHS-I memory card for anyone in need of fast, reliable storage for their high-performance devices.

location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 21, 2019
text: Card could not be recognized by multiple cameras for long periods of time. Intermittently would work, but then fail again. I initially thought it was my new camera that was acting up, so I spent a lot of time updating software and reformatting this card. Eventually after working with camera maker, I decided to buy a card for $30 and it worked great. Clearly this card is not worth the money and you are better off spending the extra $20 to buy a card that works properly and avoid the hassle I went through.

title: Great microSD for PC/Nintendo Switch
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 1, 2022
text: Used this both in my laptop and with my Nintendo Switch. Worked great and was very easy to format, no problems encountered. Storage speeds are surprisingly fast. Turns out my write speeds were limited by my laptop hardware over the actually microSD card itself. This thing is truly next-generation in terms of speed and storage. Its crazy to think 256 GB can fit on my pinky nail but SanDisk has done it and at a tolerable price too. Price it pretty good compared to competitors especially if picked up during Prime sales.

product_name: SanDisk 256GB Extreme microSDXC UHS-I Memory Card with Adapter - Up to 190MB/s, C10, U3, V30, 4K, 5K, A2, Micro SD Card - SDSQXAV-256G-GN6MA
title: FAKE 32 mb, not 32 gigs
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 24, 2020
text: See attached pic, plus slowest write/read speed. Plus amazon not being as helpful with return as it wants me to box it to return it?! I don't want this bad FAKE card to get resold as used to go to one of you reading this. Do not risk it. Not worth the hassle nor risk.

text: First of all, this is indeed a 1TB microSD card and it will show around 953.5GB after being formatted. Some people doesn't realize the size lowers after being formatted which is natural.My only complain is the speed. The advertised speed on the package is up to 190MB read and 130MB write for this Sandisk Extreme 1TB but I only get about 80+MB/s read and 70+MB/s write. This is still pretty fast but far below the advertised speeds. I have a feeling though this is due to my SD card reader not being able to fully utilize the speed of this micro SD.This microSD card works great on the Steam Deck, especially if you are going to download gigs of games onto it. The fast write speeds helps a lot!

title: This Extreme MICROSD is my goto SD because it will never be the bottleneck when taking videos
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 14, 2022
text: I've been using the SanDisk Extreme micro SD cards for a few years now because they are the most reliable when taking high resolution video with action cameras, security cameras, dash cams and phone devices.  I've found other cheaper cards will slow down or skip frames when using the most demanding modes whereas using this card will never be the source of your bottlenecks and you have enough settings and whatnot to worry about without having to compromise your video speed or resolution because your camera cannot write files fast enough.  Using this card you will have all your camera's modes available to you, as I've found using slower cards will mean the higher modes will be unavailable (greyed out)  in your device or they will stop recording without notice.  Nothing worse than getting a once in a lifetime shot to find out your camera error-ed when you go back to edit what you thought you captured. Never again don't try to save a couple bucks, just get this card and have peace of mind.

title: Good, but buy from a supported seller, and test it to make sure.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on November 29, 2022
text: I got one and plugged it into my phone. It was recognized right away. I didn't quite trust that it wasn't a fake device so I downloaded some Linux isos (40G of them, about 10) and copied them 20 odd times to new directories. (Solid File Explorer, but any of them would have worked.) It took a while but you just let it run in the background.Once full, I did a MD5 hash of random files and always got the same correct results. I took it, formatted it again as ExFat in Windows, and it's been working fine since.  (I'm sure the original format would have been just fine come but it didn't want to bother to delete them.)It works just fine, what more can I say? It's slightly slower than internal memory, but that's the case with all SD cards, so not a problem.ExFat on Windows has a default 128KB block size, but that's changeable both downwards and upwards. I'd do It for less wasted space but concerned that the file system code for non-default block sizes might not be 100%; in addition I didn't want to waste the 2x/4x extra memory space required to mount the device. To have 1T storage I think I can spare a few extra 64k blocks.Remember to make sure your device supports a 1 TB SD card, not all phones do. (I think the over-maximum space just wouldn't be available to start with, not that the card would break,)

title: Best Micro-SD Card For Steam Deck
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 18, 2022
text: After much research, I decided to use a fast micro sd card for my primary storage in my steam deck, over replacing the internal ssd. I determined that the likely best micro SD card type for my steam deck would be one which has the following specs… XC I / U3 / A2. I then decided to stick with SanDisk because it matches most of my other cards which I’m happy with. Finally I decided that 1 TB is the capacity I was looking for. I still feel that the 1 TB takes a slightly higher than desirable price jump over the lower capacity models. But in this case it was needed. So I went ahead and purchased.I am very happy with the card. It’s performance is fantastic and works great in my Steam Deck. It serves as my primary storage and allows huge AAA games to be loaded and played as if they were on the internal storage. I’m very happy with this card and would definitely recommend it to anyone who can afford it.

I was getting close to full on the 512GB card in my phone and needed more space.It was just the ticket to double my storage capacity and works like a charm.The only down side is the time it takes to transfer the data to the new microSD card. In my case, I'm a music junkie and I didn't want to remove anything from my collection, so I needed to copy all the data from the old card to the new one. It literally takes days to move all that data, but if you're working with that much data, it should come as no surprise. MicroSDs are not hard drives or SSDs when it comes to speed, so patience is a virtue, but the reward is more space for more data!If you need the space, make the jump!

text: I got this during the black Friday sale for less than it normally goes for, it works perfectly in my Switch and I have more space than I will (probably) ever need.  Just make sure when you buy large SD cards like this, that you are getting legitimate ones from the manufacturer, as there are plenty of fake/counterfeit cards (some with fake Sandisk labeling) that are not the capacity advertised.  Use good judgement and only buy from reputable sellers (preferably the manufacturer themself).
